awd_titl_txt: Scalable Manufacturing of Perovskite Photovoltaics by Controlled Crystallization During Slot Die Coating
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports research that contributes new knowledge related to a novel process for manufacturing solar panels. This research focuses on perovskite solar cells, a new type of solar cell with the potential to revolutionize the solar cell industry due to power conversion efficiencies that surpass those of state-of-the-art solar technologies. However, perovskite solar cells are currently made using slow, low yield, laboratory-scale processes that are not amenable to be scaled up to the large areas and high throughputs required for industrial production. To overcome these barriers, this project investigates a continuous slot-die coating and crystallization process that enables the fabrication of high-quality perovskite thin films, and ultimately large-area solar panels, at high speed and low cost. Perovskite solar panels have the potential to provide electricity at lower cost than other solar technologies and could provide a boost to the U.S. renewable energy industry. This research involves several disciplines including manufacturing, engineering, and materials science and helps broaden participation of women and students from underrepresented minority groups in research and positively impacts engineering education. 

Efficient, low-cost photovoltaics (PVs) based upon perovskites have the potential to transform the global energy portfolio. The greatest remaining challenge in perovskite PVs is the development of scalable, rapid manufacturing strategies that maintain the perovskite performance at low cost. Prior knowledge of processing-structure-property relationships in PV films shows that performance depends on microstructure, composition, thickness, uniformity, and stability of the wet film during deposition, drying, and thermal treatment. This project focuses on understanding the crystallization and microstructure formation during slot-die coating, drying, and annealing processes as well as validating transport and kinetic models with experiments to control the properties of the perovskite films during processing and scale-up. The key scientific outcomes are rheological and interfacial assessment of slot-die ink formulations, a predictive nucleation and growth model accounting for thermal and concentration gradients during slot-die coating, validation of retrograde solubility (i.e. inverse temperature crystallization) as an engineering control for crystal nucleation, and evaluation of double slot-die coating to create composition gradients and thereby decouple crystallization from drying. This allows for rationally designed inks for perovskite synthesis and a road map to address the challenges of coupled drying and crystallization common to rapid polycrystalline thin-film manufacturing processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Professors Jason Baxter, Nicolas Alvarez, Richard Cairncross, and Aaron Fafarman at Drexel University recently completed research for their award CMMI-1933819, studying the crystallization of halide perovskite thin films of interest for next-generation solar cells. These perovskite materials have demonstrated excellent properties for converting sunlight into electricity, and solar cells based on halide perovskite have achieved power conversion efficiencies competitive with commercial technologies.  Perovskite solar panels have the potential to provide electricity at lower cost than other solar technologies and could provide a boost to the U.S. renewable energy industry. However, most research and development of perovskite thin films has relied on slow and wasteful laboratory-scale processes that are not easily scaled up to the high throughput and large areas needed for industrial manufacturing. To overcome these barriers, this research project investigated a continuous slot-die coating and crystallization process from ink-like solutions that can enable the fabrication of high-quality perovskite thin films, and ultimately large-area solar panels, at high speed and low cost.

In solution coating, a wet film of the ink is distributed onto a solid substrate, and a solid film forms as the solvent evaporates.  The film thickness, uniformity, and microstructure depend sensitively on the interplay between drying, solute diffusion, and crystal nucleation and growth. The team combined their complementary knowledge of coatings, rheology, transport modeling, halide perovskite materials chemistry, and thin film solar cells to advance knowledge of crystallization from different solvents, develop promising new ink formulations compatible with high-throughput manufacturing, and build understanding of process-structure-property relationships. One highlight was development of a quasi-2-dimensional model to predict solid microstructure in drying thin films.  The model enabled development of a process map that can guide selection of processing choices to achieve uniform films.  Researchers at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory saw great value in this model, leading to a PhD student internship and new collaborations to further develop and apply the concepts to a wider range of industry-relevant ink formulations and processing scenarios.  The Drexel team has additionally investigated deposition of perovskite thin films from new ink formulations that are based on environmentally friendly solvents and that can be processed at lower temperature than those conventionally used in the laboratory.  These developments are of interest to the many U.S.-based perovskite start-up companies and could further enable and accelerate a transition to future domestic manufacturing of low-cost, high-efficiency perovskite solar panels.

This grant provided support for education and training of two PhD students and one postdoctoral researcher. Additionally, one masters student and four undergraduate students contributed to this research.  After completing their work at Drexel, these researchers entered the next phases of their careers at places including First Solar, Teledyne, University of Pennsylvania, and University of California San Diego.  The Drexel team has also led outreach activities to bring the excitement of engineering and solar energy to K – 8th grade students. The Drexel team annually hosted Junior Solar Sprint, where middle school students build and race shoebox-sized solar-powered cars.  They also contributed to a demo on the science of light at the annual Philly Materials Day.

Detailed research results have been disseminated to the research community and are also accessible to the general public.  When the current students graduate, this research grant will have resulted in 6 publications in peer-reviewed journals, 5 conference presentations, 2 PhD theses, and 1 MS thesis. 

 


Last Modified: 03/01/2024
Modified by: Jason B Baxter

Image
  • Overall scheme for this project to understand and control film formation during scalable manufacturing of perovskite solar cells.
